Faculty of Metallurgy and Energy Engineering Kunming University of Science and Technology Kunming China Vanillin hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) was studied in water and methanol using palladium-decorated carbon dots (Pd/CDs). The catalyst was synthesized from photo-reduction of palladium acetate using CDs as the reducing and dispersion agent, while CDs were produced via microwave treatment of glucose and urea. Pd/CDs were characterized with XRD, TEM, FT-IR, XPS, BET and ICP-OES. The selectivity to 2‑methoxy-4-methylphenol (MMP), at vanillin conversion of 100 % after 4.0 h was 98.8 % at 140 °C under 4.0 MPa of H2 in water with 4.58 wt.% of Pd/CDs. The stability of Pd/CDs was also investigated after four times recycle under the optimal reaction conditions. CDs supported Pd reduced with NaBH4 and hydrazine hydrate (Pd/CDs-S and Pd/CDs-H) and other carbonaceous materials (active carbon and OH functionalized multi-walled carbon nanotube) supported Pd (Pd/AC and Pd/CNTs) were also investigated for comparison. The highest selectivity to MMP achieved by Pd/CDs produced via photoreduction brings a novel use of this type of catalyst in the conversion of biomass into value-added chemicals and materials. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbon dots Pd/CDs Hydrodeoxygenation Vanillin 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Because of the advantages of wide source, abundant reserves and clean utilization, lignocellulosic biomass has become an important raw source for chemical synthesis. However, the complex macromolecular structure of lignocellulose makes it difficult to be utilized [1]. One of the major challenges or bottlenecks is the degradation or conversion of lignin, as it is the recalcitrant part in lignocellulose, and is the most difficult to be effectively utilized. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is a feasible and widely studied approach used in chemical transformation of lignocellulose and the catalytic upgrading of crude biofuels. It effectively destroys the recalcitrant structure of lignocellulose, and can convert lignin derivatives (phenols, guaiacols, syringols, alcohols, and ethers) to valuable biofuels and chemicals [2]. Vanillin is a representative platform molecule derived from lignin, which contains three functional groups of phenolic hydroxyl, methoxy and aldehyde. Selective conversion of vanillin to 2‑methoxy-4-methylphenol (MMP) has recently attracted great attentions since the produced MMP can be used as a promise chemical intermediate and potential biofuel [3]. Many heterogeneous catalysts have been used for the production of MMP from vanillin, among which the Pd-based catalysts show the most excellent catalytic activity [4]. Pd nanoparticles (NPs) (2.0 wt.%) supported on chemically activated carbon were active for HDO of vanillin, and MMP selectivity reached 92 % over the resultant catalyst at 100 °C for 3 h [4]. MMP selectivity of >99 % was detected from vanillin catalyzed by Pd@NH2-UiO-66 at 100 °C for 1.0 h [5]. The Pd@biocarbon catalyst activated by K2FeO4 and carbonized at 800 °C could achieve vanillin conversion of 95 % at low temperature of 65 °C, but the selectivity of MMP was below 30 % [6]. On the other hand, high MMP selectivity from HDO of vanillin were reported in organic solvents such as n-butanol [7]. and ethanol [8]. Although lots of Pd based catalysts have been exploited for the production of MMP through HDO of vanillin effectively, it should be noted that intricate procedures were critical to synthesize the resultant catalyst and excessive usage of organic solvents was necessary to promote the production of MMP [9]. Carbon dots (CDs) are generally recognized as nanomaterials and extensively employed in diverse research fields, including bioimaging, sonocatalysis, energy storage, electronics, and organic transformation reactions [10]. Recently, CDs have attracted great interests in diverse fields because of their unique characteristics such as photoluminescence performance, [11] low toxicity, [12] large specific surface area [13] and easy modification and functionalization [14]. Abundant electrons and holes on the surface of CDs make CDs acting either as oxidizing agent or reducing agent in some cases. Additionally, CDs have numerous functional groups such as -OH, -NH2 and -COOH on their surface, which benefits the coordination of CDs with metal ions and stabilizes metal nanoparticles [15]. Metal particles of Ag [16] and Au [17] in nano size were prepared using CDs both as reducing and stabilizing agents. The nanocomposites of metal supported on CDs showed prospective catalytic activity in C-C bond formation reaction, oxidation reaction, oxidative cleavage, reduction reaction, and hydrogenation reaction, etc [18]. Rh NPs were directly reduced from Rh3+ by CDs, and the result Rh/CDs NPs showed excellent activity in the catalytic hydrogenation of hydroxyl‑terminated polybutadiene [19]. Beside, Ru/CDs catalyst showed high potential in the application of both oxidation and reduction reactions [20]. However, there are few studies on the preparation of metal/CDs nanoparticles with HDO activity in the HDO of lignin derivatives [21]. Regarding the catalyst preparation, photochemically synthesis method is excellent to get highly dispersed and active catalysts with relatively simple process at low energy cost [22]. Garcia et al [23]. used light reduction method to prepare highly dispersed Au/TiO2 catalyst, and Au/TiO2 catalyst has a high catalytic activity for guaiacol HDO (the conversion rate of guaiacol is 99.9 % and the selectivity of cyclohexane is 95.1 % at 280 °C). Cao et al. [24] successfully synthesized Pt/CDs and Au/CDs nanoparticles reduced by CDs under UV light, and used them for the reduction of CO2. The results showed that the conversion rate of CO2 was much higher than other similar catalysts. Song et al. prepared reduced CDs by hydrothermal method using oligosaccharide α-cyclodextrin as carbon source, and successfully reduced Ag+ in AgCl solution under UV light to prepare Ag/CDs composite nanocatalyst [25]. In this work, Pd/CDs composite catalyst was prepared under ultraviolet (UV) light by using novel CDs as reducing agent and supporting material, and was used in the HDO of vanillin to produce MMP. The morphology and structure of Pd/CDs were characterized by XRD, TEM, FT-IR, XPS, BET and ICP-OES, and its activity in HDO of vanillin at different reaction conditions and the distribution of products were discussed. The CDs supported Pd NPs catalysts reduced solely by CDs under UV show higher MMP selectivity compared to other catalysts studied in this work. The present work provides an idea for designing CDs supported metal catalyst for vanillin HDO. 2 Experiments 2.1 Materials Glucose, urea, palladium acetate, methanol, ethanol and vanillin (99.5 %) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Active charcoal powder were purchased from Fuchen Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. (Tianjin, China). OH functionalized multi-walled carbon nanotubes (OD: 30–80 nm, length: 0.5–2 μm) and N2H4 .H2O (≥80 %) were purchased from East Sichuan Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. (Chongqing, China). Vanillyl alcohol (98 %), NaBH4 and 2‑methoxy-4-methylphenol (98 %) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All the chemicals were analytically pure and were used as received without further purification. The water used in all experiments was ultrapure (18.2MΩ) prepared with CLXXXUFM2 (ELGA). 2.2 Synthesis of CDs CDs were synthesized under microwave with glucose and urea as feedstock according to the literature [26]. Initially, glucose (1 g) and urea (0.2 g) were dissolved in 50 mL deionized water in a 100 mL conical flask. The aqueous solution was heated in a microwave oven at 700 W for 10 min. The obtained black-colored solution was diluted with 20 mL of deionized water and then centrifuged at 12,000 rpm for 5 min. The supernatant was dialyzed against deionized water using a membrane (molecular weight cut-off (MWCO) of 500 Da) for 48 h to collect pure CDs. Finally, the pure CDs were dried at 60 °C in a vacuum oven for 48 h to obtain CDs powder. 2.3 Synthesis of the Pd/CDs catalyst The Pd/CDs composite catalyst was synthesized with the photochemical method, as shown in Fig. 1 . 160 mg of the reduced CDs was accurately weighed and fully dispersed in 100 mL deionized water with the help of ultrasound to obtain the CDs solution for later use. Then 16 mg of palladium acetate was weighed and dissolved in 20 mL of ethanol solution, which was shaken for 5 min to fully dissolve, and then added to the CDs solution drop by drop under the condition of 400 rpm magnetic agitation. The mixed solution was reduced under 365 nm UV light for 2.0 h, and then aged after stirring for 2.0 h. Pd/CDs with 5 wt.% of Pd were obtained by centrifugation, washing for several times, and dried overnight in vacuum at 60 °C [27]. Similarly, Pd/CDs catalysts with different Pd metal loadings were prepared. 2.4 Synthesis of the Pd/C, Pd/CNTs, Pd/CDs-S and Pd/CDs-H catalyst An impregnation-reduction method was followed to prepare these catalysts with a nominal Pd loading of 5.0 wt.%. Typically, 100 mg Pd(CH3COO)2 was dissolved in 25 ml ethanol through sonication for 1 h, and 1 g active charcoal was added into the solution which was vigorously stirred for another 1.5 h. Then 7 mL of NaBH4 aqueous solution (9 mg/mL) was added dropwise into the mixture, stirred for 2 h and further aged for 12 h without stirring. The black catalyst was obtained by centrifugation, washing with ethanol followed by water for three times, dried overnight in vacuum at 60 °C, and denoted as Pd/C. The same method was employed to produce a Pd/CNTs catalyst by using CNTs as support and a Pd/CDs-S catalyst by using CDs as support. A Pd/CDs-H catalyst was also synthesized with the same method except using N2H4 .H2O (7 mL, 9 mg/mL) as reduction agent. 2.5 Characterization methods of catalysts Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of CDs and Pd/CDs were recorded using JEOL JEM-2100 (Tokyo, Japan), and EDX analysis was performed at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Infrared spectra were measured with a Thermo Fisher Scientific Nicolet iS10 Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer (Waltham, WA) at scanning range of 4000∼400 cm−1, scanning times of 16 and resolution of 4 cm−1(KBr pellets). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded with a Niko D/MAX-2200 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation, at minimum angle step of 1/1000°, scanning speed of 5°/min and in the scanning range of 10–90°. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was measured using an ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Massachusetts, USA) with the binding energy corrected according to the standard of surface contamination C1s (284.8 eV). The samples were analyzed using a monochromatic Al X-ray source operation at 72 W, with the signal averaged over an oval-shape area of 600 × 400 μm. The XPS operation conditions were as follow: vacuum degree: ∼2 × 10−7 mbar, full spectrum scanning energy: 100 eV, step size: 1 eV; narrow spectrum scanning energy: 30 eV, step size: 0.1 eV. Avantage software was used for the analysis of the data. The surface area and pore information were measured by the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller method (BET) and BJH methods from N2 physisorption isotherms tested on Micrometrics ASAP 2010. The Pd content in Pd/CDs catalyst was detected by ICP-OES analysis (Agilent ICP-OES 730). 2.6 Catalytic HDO of vanillin The catalytic HDO of vanillin was carried out in a Parr 50 mL autoclave (Parr Instrument Company, Houston, USA) with a mechanical stirrer, a pressure gauge and an automatic temperature control apparatus. Vanillin HDO was performed in 35 mL of distilled water, methanol or mixture of water and methanol using 50–500 mg of vanillin and 10–40 mg of catalyst. After loading vanillin, solvent and catalyst into the reactor, it was purged with N2 three times, and then pressurized with H2 to a setting pressure. The reactor was then heated to the desired temperature with the stirring speed of 320 rpm to eliminate the diffusion effect. After the reaction, the samples were separated by centrifugation. The liquid products were analyzed by using a gas chromatography mass spectrometry (GCMS–) of GC HP6890 coupling with MS HP5973. The liquid products were also detected by a Shimadzu 2018 gas chromatography (GC) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a capillary column Rtx-Wax 240 (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm). The products were quantified via using an external calibration curve for vanillin, vanillyl alcohol and MMP. The carbon balance was >99 % in the HDO reactions. The conversion of vanillin and the selectivity of product i (sel.i) were calculated as follows: (1) Conversion = ( Initial mole amount − Residual mole amount ) of vanillin Initial mole amount of vanillin × 100 % (2) Sel . i = Mole amount of production i ( Initial mole amount − Residual mole amount ) of vanillin × 100 % Stability of the Pd/CDs catalysts were tested at the conditions of 100 mg vanillin, 30 mg Pd/CDs, 4.0 MPa H2, 140 °C, 4.0 h and 35 ml water over four cycles. At the end of each cycle, the Pd/CDs catalyst was recovered through filtering, washing with ethanol and drying in vacuum at room temperature overnight. No special treatment before reuse. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of CDs and Pd/CDs The XRD patterns for bare CDs and Pd/CDs are compared as shown in Fig. 2 . The XRD pattern of CDs shows an obvious broad diffraction peak at 2θ=19.98° owing to their amorphous nature. The XRD pattern of Pd/CDs exhibits the characteristic bands at 2θ=40.9°, 46.8° and 68.2°, which are assigned to the (111), (200) and (220) planes of Pd nanoparticles (NPs), respectively [JCPDS, Card No. 46-1043], and the characteristic band at 2θ=27.4°, which are assigned to PdO prills [JCPDS, Card No. 75-0584], in addition to characteristic diffraction of CDs at 2θ=16°. The reason for the shift of the diffraction peak of CDs for Pd/CDs may be due to the strong interaction between CDs and Pd, leading to a weak change in the crystal structure of CDs [28]. Moreover, the XRD patterns of Pd/C and Pd/CNTs show the diffraction peaks of the (111), (200), (220) and (311) crystal plane of Pd, and the characteristic PdO band at 2θ=27.4° without exception. The prepared CDs and corresponding supported Pd/CDs, Pd/CDs-H and Pd/CDs-S catalysts with different preparation methods were analyzed by TEM. These NPs all have good spherical morphology, uniform particle size distribution, and are dispersed without polymerization (Fig. 3 a–d). Through Nano Measurer software, 300 nanoparticles were randomly tested to get the size distribution map. For CDs, 30 % of the nanoparticles have particle size of less than 1.40 nm, while 90 % have particle size less than 2.59 nm, giving average particle size of 2.03 nm (Fig. 3e). For the Pd/CDs, 30 % of nanoparticles have particle size of less than 2.26 nm, while 90 % have particle size of less than 3.47 nm, giving average particle size of 2.86 nm (Fig. 3f). In a similar way, the Pd/CDs-H NPs synthesized with the chemical reduction using N2H4 .H2O as the reducing agent have an average particle size of 3.12 nm (Fig. 3g), and the Pd/CDs-S using NaBH4 as the reducing agent have an average particle size of 3.88 nm (Fig. 3h). In all, the catalysts exhibit particle size increased in the order: Pd/CDs < Pd/CDs-H < Pd/CDs-S. The relative larger particle size of the Pd/CDs-S could be assigned to agglomeration under the dramatic thermal effect when using NaBH4 as the reducing agent. In this work, due to the mild conditions of photoreduction method, the average particle size of Pd/CDs catalyst is the smallest. The effects of particle size on HDO of vanillin to MMP will be shown in Section 3.2. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images of CDs and Pd/CDs are shown in Fig. 4 . It can be seen that there are apparent lattice fringes with the plane spacings of 0.21 nm in CDs, closing to spacing of (110) lattice of graphitic carbon (Fig. 4a). For Pd/CDs, HRTEM image shows that Pd NPs were embedded in CDs with the crystal plane spacings of 0.23 nm and 0.20 nm assigned to Pd (111) and Pd (200) [29], respectively (Fig. 4b). CDs (110) and Pd (220) nanoparticles are closely combined, which fully indicates the successful synthesis of Pd/CDs nanocatalyst. Bright spots in selected area diffraction (SAED) pattern of CDs and Pd/CDs (Fig. 4c & d) confirm the crystalline phase of the synthesized nanocatalyst. The rings with different d-spacings of 0.22 nm and 0.23 nm are indexed with the face-centered cubic unit cell dimensions of CDs (110) and Pd (111) nanoparticles (JCPDS file no.87-0638), respectively. It is also confirmed with the previous XRD characterization results. The presence of Pd in the Pd/CDs catalyst is also confirmed by the EDS and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis (Fig. 5 ). The FT-IR spectrum of CDs exhibits a broad peak at ∼3400 cm−1, corresponding to both O-H of carboxylic and N-H of amine-stretching vibration. Peaks at 2916, 1750, 1634, 1409, 1029 and 614 cm−1 corresponding to the -O-C=O stretching, C=O stretching, C=C stretching, O-C stretching, C-N stretching, C-O-C stretching vibration, respectively (Fig. 6 ) [30]. In the FT-IR spectrum of Pd/CDs, the same characteristic peaks of CDs can also be observed but the peak intensity at 1750 and 1029 cm−1 decrease apparently compared to that at 1634 cm−1 and 1409 cm−1, respectively. These results indicate that the functional groups of CDs are involved in the Pd NPs formation. XPS analysis was conducted to further investigate the structure of Pd/CDs. Fig. 7 shows the XPS spectrum of elements C, O, N and Pd present in the Pd/CDs. The high-resolution spectrum of the Pd 3d region of Pd/CDs reveals the presence of Pd-Pd in Pd0 species with 335.1 eV and 340.8 eV, and 342.4 eV and 337.1 eV are suggestive of the Pd2+ species formation due to the oxidation, which is a common phenomenon in noble metals (Fig. 7a) [31]. The high-resolution spectrum of the C1s (Fig. 7b) reveals the presence of C–C (284.8 eV), C–O (286.8 eV), C=O (288.3 eV) and O-C=O (289.7 eV) bonds [32]. The O1s spectrum (Fig. 7c) shows four components at 530.9, 532, 533 and 534.1 eV, corresponding to C-OH, C-O, C=O and O-C=O bonds, respectively. These peaks demonstrate the presence of hydroxyl, carbonyl and carboxylic acid groups on the Pd/CDs surface. For N1s, the peak could be deconvoluted into two sub-peaks at 399.9 and 401.9 eV (Fig. 7d), which are attributed to C-N and N-H bonds, respectively [15]. These N-atoms might be associate with the reduction of Pd2+ to form the Pd NPs catalysts [32]. The element compositions of the Pd/CDs with 5 wt.% of Pd were measured by TEM-EDS, XPS and ICP-OES. As shown in Table 1 , the elemental composition of C, O, N, Pd measured by TEM-EDS, and the O, N, Pd elemental is close to the value by XPS. The actual amount of Pd in the catalyst measured by ICP-OES is 4.58 wt.%, closed to the theoretical value, suggesting the accurate precipitation of Pd on CDs [33]. The textural features of CDs and Pd/CDs were investigated by BET analysis as shown in Table 2 . It is found that they have relatively low specific surface area of 16.0 and 9.7 m2·g−1, respectively. With the introduction of Pd particles, the pore volume and the average pore diameter of Pd/CDs both decrease slightly, which indicates that Pd occupies part of the pore of CDs. Moreover, the N2 adsorption-desorption of CDs and Pd/CDs both exhibit type IV isotherms (Fig. 8 ). There is also an obvious Type H4 hysteresis loop, indicating that the material has the characteristics of typical mesoporous materials [34] 3.2 Catalytic HDO of vanillin over Pd/CDs The HDO of vanillin was used to test the catalytic activity of the Pd/CDs nanohybrids. Firstly, the influence of methanol-to-water volume ratio on the catalytic activity of Pd/CDs for the HDO of vanillin was investigated, as shown in Fig. 9 . With only methanol as solvent, the conversion of vanillin was 68 %, and the selectivity of MMP was only 17 % because methyl vanillyl ether (MVE) was formed as main by-product with the selectivity of 71 %. The MVE was produced by reaction of vanillyl alcohol with methanol [35]. It is worthwhile to notice that water could accelerate the conversion of vanillin and the production of MMP. With the decrease of the ratio of methanol to water, the selectivity of MMP was continuously improved. When the solvent was changed to water, the conversion of vanillin reached to 100 %, and the selectivity of MMP increased to 98.8 %. The total ions flow diagram of GC–MS for this product is shown in Fig. 10 . In addition to MMP and vanillyl alcohol, there were only trace amount of unknown byproducts. The results showed that water promotes the hydrogenolysis of vanillyl alcohol into MMP and is the best solvent for the HDO of vanillin. Some studies indicated that the presence of water facilitated the vanillin HDO due to the interaction between vanillin and water, which resulted in a strong stabilization of transition states and consequently accelerated reaction rates [36]. So the HDO of vanillin in water would have the advantages of being sustainable and environmentally-friendly than in organic solvents. Based on the results above, the possible reaction network of vanillin HDO is proposed, as shown in Fig. 11 . Under the action of Pd/CDs catalyst, the C=O on the -CHO of vanillin is firstly hydrogenated to form vanillin alcohol, and then the hydroxyl group of alcohol is further hydrodehydrated to form -CH3. However, when methanol is used as a solvent, vanillyl alcohol reactes with methanol through etherification to MVE [37]. The influences of vanillin/catalyst mass ratio, reaction temperature and time, H2 pressure and Pd loading on the catalytic activity of Pd/CDs for HDO of vanillin in water were investigated systemically. The conversion of vanillin is 60.2 %, and the selectivity of vanillyl alcohol and MMP is 36.9 % and 40.6 %, respectively at the vanillin/catalyst mass ratio of 16.7. With the vanillin/catalyst mass ratio decrease, the conversion of vanillin and the selectivity of MMP gradually increases (Fig. 12 ). When the vanillin/catalyst mass ratio is 3.3 or even lower, vanillin conversion could reach 100 % with 98.8 % of MMP selectivity. This change could be attributed to increased competition for a finite number of active sites on the catalyst surface [38]. In the study of vanillin HDO over Pd/C catalyst by Elias et al., they found that the activity of the catalyst and the initial reaction rate decreased as the starting concentration of vanillin increased [38]. On the other hand, because the competition of vanillin for sites on the catalyst surface is stronger than that of vanillyl alcohol, the HDO pathway is suppressed, resulting in selectivity of MMP dropping dramatically with increasing initial amount of vanillin. While the activation of vanillin might have relatively lower demand on the available quantity of catalyst sites, thus the hydrogenation level of vanillin towards vanillyl alcohol is parallelly decreased with the reduced adsorption ratio and total conversion of vanillin over the fixed catalyst dosage. Namely, the selectivity of vanillyl alcohol remains constant. The effect of reaction temperature on the activity of Pd/CDs for the HDO of vanillin is shown in Fig. 13 . Results show that the selectivity of products changes significantly with the increasing of reaction temperature. At low temperature of 110 °C, the selectivity of vanillyl alcohol is still close to 40 %. At 140 °C, the selectivity of MMP increases to 98.8 % with 100 % conversion of vanillin. But when the temperature increases to above 140 °C, the selectivity of MMP begins to decrease because MMP is converted to 2-methoxyphenol at high temperatures [39]. With the prolongation of reaction time, vanillin conversion and MMP selectivity both increase to nearly 100 % at reaction time of 4.0 h (Fig. 14 a). On the other hand, an increase in hydrogen pressure enhances the conversion of vanillin and the selectivity to MMP (Fig. 14b), and the result is in consistent with the study of vanillin HDO over Pt/C [40]. and PdRh/Al2O3 catalyst [41]. The reason is that H2 gas is the limiting reactant in the vanillin HDO, while high H2 pressure makes H2 molecules easily accessible to vanillin and active sites of catalyst [42]. To sum up, the Pd/CDs catalyst exhibited excellent performance for vanillin HDO in water with vanillin conversion of 100 % and MMP selectivity of 98.8 % at 140 °C, 4.0 h, 4.0 MPa H2, initial vanillin concentration of 100 mg and 30 mg Pd/CDs. The effect of loading amount of Pd on the vanillin HDO was investigated, as shown in Table 3 . The results show that Pd promotes the hydrogenolysis of vanillyl alcohol into MMP. When bare CDs are used as catalyst, the conversion of vanillin is only 42.7 %, and the main products are vanillyl alcohol and 2-methoxyphenol with the selectivity of 36.2 % and 21.6 %, respectively. With the increase of Pd loading on the catalyst, vanillin conversion and MMP selectivity gradually increases to the highest value of 100 % and 98.8 %, respectively at the loading ratio of Pd of 4.58 wt.%. In order to evaluate the influence of CDs on the reaction, HDO of vanillin with Pd supported on other commercially available carbonaceous materials (AC and CNTs) were conducted for comparison. All experiments were conducted under the conditions of 4.0 MPa H2, 140 °C and 4 h, and the results are presented in Fig. 15 . The results indicates that despite 100 % conversions of vanillin could be achieved over Pd/C and Pd/CNTs, the MMP selectivity was 94.27 % and 78.12 % for Pd/C and Pd/CNTs, respectively, lower than that of Pd/CDs. Espinosa et al. also observed a lower MMP selectivity over CNT supported Pd NPs at similar loading than on few-layers graphene with the prismatic plane [43]. The high performance of Pd/CDs could be attributed to its small particle size and the synergistic effect between the abundant functional groups on the surface of the CDs and the Pd metal. Meanwhile, in order to assessment the effect of Pd particle size on the reaction, we compared the catalytic performance of Pd/CDs-H and Pd/CDs-S catalysts with that of Pd/CDs under the optimized reaction conditions of Pd/CDs (Fig. 15). It can be seen that all CDs supported Pd NPs could achieve complete conversion of vanillin, but the Pd/CDs catalysts with the smallest particle size (2.86 ± 0.04 nm) exhibited the greatest selectivity to MMP compared to the Pd/CDs-H (3.12 ± 0.05 nm) and Pd/CDs-S (3.88 ± 0.13 nm). This is a clear indication of the promotional role of small particle size in the catalytic HDO of vanillin over the Pd/CDs catalysts. Catalysts with smaller particle size have a larger specific surface area, and expose more active site, which is conducive to HDO of vanillin. The recyclability of Pd/CDs under the optimal reaction conditions was performed to explore the stability of catalyst. As shown in Fig. 16 , after four cycles, vanillin conversion was still as high as 97.8 %, while the selectivity of MMP decreased to 87.1 %. The reason may be that part of Pd leached from the surface of CDs under vigorous stirring and high temperature during the reaction (Table 4 ), resulting in the loss of active metal and reduced catalytic activity. The leaching rate of Pd metal gradually increased with the number of cycles. However, the catalyst eventually became stable after three cycles. For a comparison based on the observed conversion of vanillin, desired MMP selectivity, reaction conditions and solvent involved, the vanillin HDO activities of previously reported Pd based catalysts are tabulated in Table 5 . The newly designed Pd/CDs in present work has an outstanding activity than mostly other supported Pd-based catalysts, except for Pd/N-C (entry 2 in Table 5). The Pd/POP and Cu3Pd/BBA-1 catalysts had high vanillin conversion and MMP selectivity at temperature of 140 °C in water, however, the reaction time were as long as 18 and 8 h, respectively (entry 7 & 8). 4 Conclusions In conclusion, the CDs were synthesized by microwave-assisted hydrothermal treatment of glucose and urea, and CDs were used both as reducing agent and catalyst support in the preparation of Pd NPs by reducing of Pd2+ under 365 nm UV light. The resulting Pd/CDs nanoparticles had good dispersion with an average size of 2.86 nm. Compared with Pd-based catalysts supported on other carbonaceous materials (AC and CNTs) or resemble catalysts with relative larger metal particle size (Pd/CDs-H and Pd/CDs-S), the Pd/CDs catalyst exhibited excellent activity for vanillin HDO in water with 100 % conversion of vanillin and 98.8 % selectivity of MMP. After 4 cycles of catalyst reuse, vanillin conversion and MMP selectivity declined to 97.8 % and 87.1 %, respectively. In general, the activity of Pd/CDs was superior to other catalysts reported in literatures due to the smaller particle size achieved by photoreduction method, except for slightly less stable. Therefore, the findings of this work will provide a feasible method to synthesize hybrid catalysts of metal over CDs, and exhibit the potential in the synthesis of high value-added biofuels and chemicals from conversion of lignin derivatives. coredata.dc:description: Vanillin hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) was studied in water and methanol using palladium-decorated carbon dots (Pd/CDs). The catalyst was synthesized from photo-reduction of palladium acetate using CDs as the reducing and dispersion agent, while CDs were produced via microwave treatment of glucose and urea. Pd/CDs were characterized with XRD, TEM, FT-IR, XPS, BET and ICP-OES. The selectivity to 2‑methoxy-4-methylphenol (MMP), at vanillin conversion of 100 % after 4.0 h was 98.8 % at 140 °C under 4.0 MPa of H2 in water with 4.58 wt.% of Pd/CDs. The stability of Pd/CDs was also investigated after four times recycle under the optimal reaction conditions. CDs supported Pd reduced with NaBH4 and hydrazine hydrate (Pd/CDs-S and Pd/CDs-H) and other carbonaceous materials (active carbon and OH functionalized multi-walled carbon nanotube) supported Pd (Pd/AC and Pd/CNTs) were also investigated for comparison. The highest selectivity to MMP achieved by Pd/CDs produced via photoreduction brings a novel use of this type of catalyst in the conversion of biomass into value-added chemicals and materials.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrodeoxygenation of vanillin to 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol over carbon dots supported Pd catalyst
